title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Instructor Introduction
Hi! I’m Jessica Helmer. I’m a second-year PhD student in Quantitative Psychology.
My research focuses on the measurement and modeling of decision-making processes.

Email: jhelmer3@gatech.edu
Office: J.S. Coon Rm 240
Office Hours: Wednesdays, 10–11am, my office / Zoom


○ Or by appointment

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
section: What You Can Expect From Me
text:
What You Can Expect From Me
I am available as a resource! Please feel free to reach out / email anytime if you need help, have questions about the lab, or have any suggestions or feedback for the class.
I encourage helping each other / collaboration during the lab! While working on assignments, I will try to answer everyone’s questions as soon as I can. but if someone near you is confused and you can help, go for it!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Student Introductions

Name
Year at Georgia Tech
Major
Coding Experience?
Anything else!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Lab Assignments
Students are expected to attend and participate in all scheduled labs.
We will have a lab lecture and assignment each week (barring institute holidays).
Students are expected to work on the activity during the scheduled lab time.
Lab assignments are due on Canvas at 11:59pm the same day they are distributed.
We will not be able to accept late lab assignments!
Assignment distributed after lecture (with plenty of time to complete!)

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Lab Assignments
Always offer a few words of explanation for questions in the assignment.

○ Output alone will not get full credit.

Please submit both the knitted (.html) and the RMarkdown (.rmd) file.

○ Without your R code, we will not be able to give partial credit if the result is incorrect.

Always provide R output for every analysis carried out.

○ If the assignment asks you to make a plot, include that plot in your submission (not just the code).

Graded 0–100, equally weighted to compose 20% of your PSYC 2020 / PSYC 6022 grade

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
About AI
AI can be a very helpful tool for learning coding! Feel free to use it to clarify concepts, troubleshoot code, or syntax explanations
However, for the assignments, your code needs to be your own.
It is important to practice and gain experiencing coding independently.

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Lab Resources


Introduction to Data Exploration and Analysis with R (IDEAR)

R for Data Science (2e)


YaRrr! The Pirate’s Guide to R


All free, open source materials for learning R

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
What is R?
Open source coding language, primarily used for data analysis and data science

Coding (per the IDEAR book):

“Giving very specific instructions to a very stupid machine.”




print("Hello, World!")

[1] "Hello, World!"

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Why R?
Because R is a programming language, you can make your own codes / functions as commands
R has many “packages” for statistical functions
R is open source: you can see the exact code that underlies the functions you use

○ And if you’d like, you can modify it

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
What is RStudio?
An interface for R
Helps keep R files organize
Helps “knit” code, output, and text to create reports

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Installing R
We need to download two things:
R and RStudio
R is the language, RStudio is an Interactive Development Environment (IDE)
We will use R through RStudio

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
RStudio Introduction
Files, Plots, Packages
Environment, History
Console

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Vectors

c(2, 4, 6)

[1] 2 4 6




c(1, "hello!", "Georgia Tech")

[1] "1"            "hello!"       "Georgia Tech"




c() function

Stands for “combine”



Matrix algebra!

c(1, 2, 3) / 3

[1] 0.3333333 0.6666667 1.0000000



c(1, 2, 3) / c(1, 2, 3)

[1] 1 1 1

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Data Types

c(1, 2, 3)

[1] 1 2 3



c(1, "hello!", "Georgia Tech")

[1] "1"            "hello!"       "Georgia Tech"



Quotes around 1 in the first vector, not in the second


Vectors can only hold one type of data!

Numeric
Character




c(1, 2, 3) / 3

[1] 0.3333333 0.6666667 1.0000000



c(1, "hello!", "Georgia Tech") / 3

Error in c(1, "hello!", "Georgia Tech")/3: non-numeric argument to binary operator



Error because we cannot divide characters

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Data Types

TRUE

[1] TRUE




c(1, "hello!", TRUE)

[1] "1"      "hello!" "TRUE"  





c(TRUE, FALSE)

[1]  TRUE FALSE

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Data Types: Logical (boolean)

6 > 4

[1] TRUE




12 / 2 < 6

[1] FALSE





The <, >, and <= symbols are logical operators
Logical data handled like binary numeric data

TRUE == 1

[1] TRUE



FALSE + 3

[1] 3



TRUE and FALSE can be abbreviated as T and F

TRUE == T

[1] TRUE



FALSE == F

[1] TRUE



Harder to tell apart, so be careful!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Practice Break!

2 + 2



[1] 4




2 + 2 / 2



[1] 3





2 + 2 / 2 ^ 2



[1] 2.5





c("hello!", 2) / 2



Error in c("hello!", 2)/2: non-numeric argument to binary operator

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Variable Assignment
In R, we can assign objects (including functions) to some variable with the assignment operator <-

# assign variable a the value 1
a <- 1

# print a
a

[1] 1

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Variable Assignment

a <- c(1, 2, 3)
a

[1] 1 2 3



a <- c("Hello, world!")
a

[1] "Hello, world!"


Every time we reassign a value to a, it holds that new value
Overwrites previous value!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Variable Assignment
Overwriting can mess stuff up!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
section: Variables in Statistics: Numeric vs. Categorical
text:
Variables in Statistics: Numeric vs. Categorical
Numeric

○ Quantitative


○ Values describing a measurable quantity as a number


○ “How many” or “how much”

Categorical

○ Distinguish distinct elements or entities


○ Name, gender, ethnicity…

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Four Types of Measurement


Nominal

○ Variable that represents categories without any inherent order.


○ E.g., types of fruit (“apple,”“orange,” “banana”).

Ordinal

○ Variable that represents categories with a meaningful order.


○ For example, levels of satisfaction (“very unsatisfied,” “unsatisfied,” “neutral,” “satisfied,” “very satisfied”)


Discrete

○ Variable that can only take specific values.


○ Think of things you can count, like the number of people in a room or the number of apples in a basket.

Continuous

○ Variable that can take any value within a range.


○ Think of things you can measure, like height or time.

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Dataframes
Table of data
Can make by hand with the data.frame() function:

data.frame(x = c(1, 2, 3),
           y = c("a", "b", "c"),
           z = c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE))

  x y     z
1 1 a  TRUE
2 2 b FALSE
3 3 c  TRUE


Shift+Enter to go to new line on Console
Most of the time, we import data (and don’t manually type it in)
In console, can press up arrow to reload last line of code

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Dataframes
If you already have vector objects saved, you don’t have to type them in again

a <- c(1, 2, 3)
b <- c(2, 3, 4)
c <- c(3, 4, 5)





data.frame(a = a,
           b = b,
           c = c)

  a b c
1 1 2 3
2 2 3 4
3 3 4 5




data.frame(a, b, c)

  a b c
1 1 2 3
2 2 3 4
3 3 4 5




data.frame(A = a, b, c)

  A b c
1 1 2 3
2 2 3 4
3 3 4 5

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
R Projects
RStudio’s way of helping organizing files, scripts, etc.
I strongly recommend this!!

○ File > New Project


○ If you don’t already have a folder associated with this class, “New Directory”


○ If you do, “Existing Directory”

All R Scripts under the same project share a working directory

○ Location of files

getwd() tells us the location of our working directory
setwd("C:/Users/Desktop/R Example") sets the working directory
Or, here::here() lets us do relative directories (my favorite!)

○ Just use the command at the top of the file to see where your directory is

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
R Scripts
R script files end with .R
How to Create an R Script File

Manually


File > New File > R Script


Shortcut


Ctrl + Shift + N

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
RMarkdown


A way of typesetting R code into a document
End in .rmd
File > New File > RMarkdown…
Input Title, Author, Date
How we will complete assignments

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Insert a Chunk
How to insert an RMarkdown chunk in RStudio

Manually:


○ Type ```{r}.


○ Add your R code.


○ Close the chunk with ```.


Shortcut:


○ Use the shortcut Ctrl + Alt + I (Windows) or Cmd + Option + I.


Button

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Run a Chunk
How to run RMarkdown code chunks in RStudio

Shortcut:


○ Use the shortcut Ctrl + Enter (Windows) or Ctrl + Return (Mac)


Button


Can also select a variable and run it to see its output (helpful!)

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Clearing Environement and Restarting R
Important to ensure that your code isn’t unintentionally relying on hidden objects in the environement

○ E.g., you created an object, deleted the line to create it, but R still sees it there

When you try to knit your file, it will clear, restart, and run all code

○ In the previous situation, your code would error

Clearing your environment and restarting R frequently helps you avoid this

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Clearing Environement and Restarting R


How to Clear Your Environment

Button



How to Restart R

Manually:


○ Session > Restart R.


Shortcut:


○ Use the shortcut Ctrl + Shift + F10 (Windows) or Cmd + Shift + F10.

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 1
text:
Tips for RMarkdown!
Run code often to ensure it’s working
Restart R frequently
Knitting will combine text, syntax, results, and output into a Word, PDF, or HTML file

iris dataset has measurements of 150 flowers, preloaded from R

head(iris)

1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa
2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa
3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa

5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa
6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

Can specify how many rows you want

tail(iris, n = 3)

Suggested R Workflow

Open a new script or RMarkdown file
Check (and set if needed) your working directory
Load any packages you’ll be working with
Write your code
Knit and save your file

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Review of Central Tendency!
Mean: Sum of all values divided by the total number of values
Median: When sorted lowest to highest, the middle value
Mode: The value that appears most often

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:

c(0, 2, 2, 4)

What is the median?
What is the mode?

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Central Tendency in R: Mean
We can calculate central tendencies in two ways:
Given this dataset, calculate the mean

c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4)

[1]  2  3 12  4  4




By hand (computer)

# let's calculate the mean!



With the mean() function

# let's calculate the mean!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Central Tendency in R: Median
Given this dataset, calculate the median

c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4)

[1]  2  3 12  4  4

c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4)[order(c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4))][(length(c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4)) + 1) / 2]

[1] 4




By hand (computer)

# let's calculate the median!



With the median() function

# let's calculate the median!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Central Tendency in R: Mode
Given this dataset, calculate the mode

c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4)

[1]  2  3 12  4  4


With the mode() function

# let's calculate the mode!



Doesn’t work :(
Have to create our own

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
R Functions
We’ve seen some built-in R functions (e.g., mean(), median())
But we can also make our own
function_name <- function(argument) {
  do some stuff
  return(this stuff)
}
Don’t actually need to call return()
R will automatically return the last expression
Then, you can call the function
function_name(specific_argument)
To keep the results, make sure to assign them to some variable
very_important_results <- function_name(specific_argument)

Let’s go back to finding the mode

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Central Tendency in R: Mode
Given this dataset, calculate the mode

c(2, 3, 12, 4, 4)

[1]  2  3 12  4  4

my_mode <- function(x) {
  values <- unique(x)
  counts <- tabulate(match(x, values))
  max_index <- which.max(counts)
  values[max_index]
}

How does this work?

# let's calculate the mode!

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Measures of Variability Functions

testscores <- c(88, 93, 92, 99, 96)

Variance: var() function
Standard Deviation: sd() function
Interquartile Range:: IQR() function
Difference between the 3rd and 1st quantile (so 50% of the data within this range)
25% of the data lower than the 1st quantile
75% of the data lower than the 3rd quantile
IQR = 3rd - 1st
Let’s look at some variances!

# let's look at some variances!



Quantiles: quantile() function

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Descriptive Statistics in R
Takes time to look at all these for a lot of variables, even with functions
The summary() function provides us a quick overview of this information

# let's get descriptive statistics for the iris dataset


What all do we get?

Minimum and maximum
1st quantile, median, 3rd quantile
Mean

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations!
Summary statistics are great, but don’t trust them alone!
What do you think a dataset with these descriptives would look like?

X_mean <- 54.26
Y_mean <- 47.83

X_sd <- 16.76
Y_sd <- 26.93

cor <- -0.06

text:
Visualizations!



Datasaurus Dozen



https://www.research.autodesk.com/publications/same-stats-different-graphs/

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations
Don’t rush: graph your data!
What should graphs do?
1. Show the data
2. The reader should be drawn primarily to the data (not the graphical effects)
3. Avoid distorting the data
4. Present many numbers with minimum ink
5. Make large data sets coherent
6. Encourage the reader to compare different pieces of data

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations: Histograms


An example of (simulated) SAT scores
What do we see here?

Outliers at zero! Not a possible SAT score


Negatively skewed: more data on the left than on the right

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Skew



Positive Skew, right-tailed
The mass of the distribution is concentrated on the left of the figure



Negative Skew, left-tailed
The mass of the distribution is concentrated on the right of the figure

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics
R has some plotting features built in—we saw this last week


plot(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Sepal.Width)










But we did not love this!


plot(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Sepal.Width,
     pch = 19,                 # solid circles
     col = "#377EB8",           # pleasant blue
     cex = 1.3,                 # slightly larger points
     xlab = "Sepal Length",     # cleaner label
     ylab = "Sepal Width",
     main = "Sepal Length vs Sepal Width",
     cex.lab = 1.2,             # bigger axis labels
     cex.main = 1.4,            # bigger title
     font.main = 2)             # bold title

# Light grid lines for readability
grid(col = "gray80", lty = "dotted")








We will learn a few plots in base R plotting, and then we will learn a better way of making plots: ggplot2

R Graph Gallery

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics: Histogram


You can make histograms with the hist() function
Its arguments are:

Required arguments:

x = Vector (variable) you want to plot (remember the $ function!)
Subarguments (check by “?hist”):

breaks: number of bins
main: title
xlab: label for x-axis
ylab: label for y-axis
border: color for bar borders
col: color for bars
xlim: range for x-axis
prob: T/F, y-axis proportion instead of frequency

If you do not set specific values for non-essential subarguments, it will use the default


hist(iris$Sepal.Length,
     breaks = 7,
     main = "Histogram of Sepal Length",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     xlim = c(3, 9),
     border = "white",
     col = "skyblue")

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics: Histogram
An important decision for histograms is this number (or width) of bins
Specified with the breaks argument



hist(iris$Sepal.Length,
     breaks = 3,
     main = "Histogram of Sepal Length",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     xlim = c(3, 9),
     border = "white",
     col = "skyblue")










hist(iris$Sepal.Length,
     breaks = 10,
     main = "Histogram of Sepal Length",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     xlim = c(3, 9),
     border = "white",
     col = "skyblue")

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics: Histogram
An important decision for histograms is this number (or width) of bins
Specified with the breaks argument



hist(iris$Sepal.Length,
     breaks = 20,
     main = "Histogram of Sepal Length",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     xlim = c(3, 9),
     border = "white",
     col = "skyblue")










hist(iris$Sepal.Length,
     breaks = 100,
     main = "Histogram of Sepal Length",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     xlim = c(3, 9),
     border = "white",
     col = "skyblue")

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics: Histogram
If we could make the bins infinitesimally small, we could get a probability density function (PDF)

PlotCode














dat <- data.frame(x = rnorm(1000))

cowplot::plot_grid(
  plotlist = list(
    ggplot(dat, aes(x = x)) +
      geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)),
                     bins = 10) +
      coord_cartesian(xlim = c(-4, 4), ylim = c(0, .5)) +
      labs(y = "Proportion") +
      cowplot::theme_cowplot(),
    
    ggplot(dat, aes(x = x)) +
      geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)),
                     bins = 50) +
      coord_cartesian(xlim = c(-4, 4), ylim = c(0, .5)) +
      labs(y = "Proportion") +
      cowplot::theme_cowplot(),
    
    ggplot(dat, aes(x = x)) +
      geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)),
                     bins = 100) +
      coord_cartesian(xlim = c(-4, 4), ylim = c(0, .5)) +
      labs(y = "Proportion") +
      cowplot::theme_cowplot(),
    
    ggplot(dat, aes(x = x)) +
      geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)),
                     bins = 100, alpha = .8) +
      stat_function(inherit.aes = FALSE, fun = dnorm,
                    n = 101, args = list(mean = 0, sd = 1),
                    xlim = c(-4, 4),
                    color = "grey35", linewidth = 2) +
      coord_cartesian(xlim = c(-4, 4), ylim = c(0, .5)) +
      labs(y = "Proportion") +
      cowplot::theme_cowplot()
  ),
  nrow = 1)

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations: Histogram
Can describe a distribution by its “dispersion”

data.frame(x = c(rnorm(5000, 0, 1),
                 rnorm(5000, 0, 3)),
           type = rep(c("packed", "disperse"),
                      each = 5000)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = x, color = type, linetype = type)) +
  geom_density(fill = "transparent", linewidth = 1.75) +
  theme_classic(base_size = 14) +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations: Boxplots


Back to the iris dataset
Distribution of Sepal Length by species
Anatomy of a boxplot
* “Minimum”
* 25th Quantile (Q1)
* Median
* 75th Quantile (Q3)
* “Maximum”
* Points representing outliers
“Minimum” and “maximum” are not the true min and max
* Minimum: \(Q1 - 1.5 * IQR\)
* Maximum: \(Q3 + 1.5 * IQR\)
Means that the whiskers contain ~99% of the data
Rest is outliers

Outliers at zero! Not a possible SAT score


Negatively skewed: more data on the left than on the right














For more explanation of the anatomy of a boxplot, feel free to check this post out from Statistics by Jim

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations: Boxplots
One more resource for boxplot anatomy

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Visualizations: Boxplots…



Datasaurus Dozen Boxplots



https://www.research.autodesk.com/publications/same-stats-different-graphs/

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics: Boxplot


You can make boxplots with the boxplot() function
Its arguments are:

Required arguments:

x = Vector (variable) you want to plot (remember the $ function!)
Subarguments (check by “?boxplot”):

main: title
xlab: label for x-axis
ylab: label for y-axis
border: color for bar borders
col: color for bars
horizontal: T/F to switch

If you do not set specific values for non-essential subarguments, it will use the default


PlotCode














boxplot(iris$Sepal.Length,
     main = "Boxplot of Sepal Length",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     border = "gray35",
     col = "skyblue")

title: Psychological Statistics Lab 2
text:
Let’s Do Some Visualization

Base R Graphics: Boxplot


To group them, you can change the x
outcome_var ~ group_var


PlotCode














boxplot(iris$Sepal.Length ~ iris$Species,
     main = "Boxplot of Sepal Length by Species",
     xlab = "Sepal Length",
     border = "gray35",
     col = "skyblue")

1) Rename this assignment as “Lab 1 Assignment [Last, First].Rmd”

title: PSYC2020L Assignment 1
text:
R Basics

3) Compute:

a) The product of 4 * 4


b) 4 squared


c) The remainder from dividing 16 by 3


d) FALSE divided by TRUE. Why did you get this answer?



4) The output of the following two lines of code is different. Why is that?

3 + 2 / 2

[1] 4



(3 + 2) / 2

[1] 2.5




4)

a) Create a vector of your four favorite movies


b) Create a vector of the years they came out


c) Create a vector of the ratings (number of stars out of five) that YOU think they deserve


d) Put all those vectors in a dataframe with the column labels “fav_movie”, “year”, and “my_rating”



5) Show me…


The first three rows of the iris dataset


6) Plot…

A scatterplot with Petal.Length on the x and Petal.Width on the y
